-No, it is in addition to the penalty with which we are now dealing.I suggest to the AttorneyGeneral that, by allowing the penalties already in the Bill to remain, and not pressing for this, he will stand as good a chance of having the lands of Australia fairly valued, and of securing a full measure of taxation out of them, as he will do if this clause be passed as he proposes. I fail to see the object of this provision, unless it is designed as the beginning of a large scheme of land nationalization. Does the Attorney-General imagine that a man would submit to a penalty of, say,£500 and the payment of treble taxation, and yet continue to wink at the law?
- The honorable member has not had much experience of landowners, or he would know how wilful undervaluation is carried on.

- If the Government have reason to suspect, after the Act has been in operation for a time, that the penalties are insufficient, they can ask for further powers. Why should they seek to clothe themselves with these autocratic powers at the initiation of this scheme? Why assume that every land-owner is going to undervalue his land ? I have pointed out reasons why I believe that land is overvalued for shire purposes.
- In Victoria land is very much undervalued for municipal purposes.

- That is merely the honorable member's statement against that of a vast army of expert men, who have spent most of their lives in valuing land, and whose opinions count for infinitely more than do his or mine. The Minister has plenty of penal machinery elsewhere in the Bill, and I hope he will allow the matter of wilful fraud to be absolutely proved against a man before proceeding to the extreme step of confiscating his property.
- We do not confiscate it.

- The Government take it from him, at any rate. What is the difference?I hope the honorable member will not proceed to that extreme in this Bill. Give the Act a chance, and if it does not work out well, the honorable member can always come again to Parlia ment and get further penalties. My own opinion is that he has plenty in the Bill.

.- I should like to put one aspect of the matter before the Attorney-General. I am of the opinion of several members of the Opposition, that the clause is very drastic indeed, and will mean endless litigation on the part both of property owners and the Commonwealth. As practical men, we do not want to rush any individual into the Courts and subject him to expensive litigation, simply because he is a land-holder. I do not think any honorable member on this side wishes that. If there are any who do wish it, they are very few. I should like to show the Minister how a man could undervalue his estate, and at the same time not do it wilfully. In fact, at the time of making the return it would be the real value. In the Western Riverina and western portions of New South Wales and Queensland, there are times when the land is practically valueless for pastoral purposes. We have seen that happen many times. I know one man who went to Western Queensland with £70,000, and left Barcaldine railway station with nothing but his swag, so that he did not make much money by taking up land. Suppose the owner of a property had a successful year this year, and land in that district was at a good price; that then a succession of droughts began, and every year the land depreciated in value. Suppose, then, that when the owner put in his assessment at the end of the financial year, a good spring suddenly followed, and the value of the land rose by, say, 100 per cent. Would the Minister say that that man had wilfully misrepresented the case to the Commissioner, and would he then step in and take the land from him at that price?
-No.
- He could do so, under this clause.
- He could ; but he would not.

- There are two words - "shall" and "may" - to the use of which, in Acts of Parliament, I take great exception. The Attorney-General, I know, desires to do what is just. He wants to rope in those who are dishonest ; and if he kept the clause as it stood originally in the Bill, I think every honorable member would be more satisfied. It is not mv desire to punish an honest man ; but I think we all desire to punish the dishonest man. The same arguments as have been used to-day were used when the clause in the Customs Act, allowing the Crown to take goods at their invoice price, plus 10 per cent., was being considered. We were told that the Government were becoming trading merchants, and would do this, that, and the other. I think that there have been only three cases of action taken under that section of the Customs Act. I appeal to the Attorney-General to do as the honorable member for Parramatta suggests. If we find that the clauses are not drastic enough, it will be within the province of the Government and Parliament to make them more drastic.

. - I hope that the Committee will come to a division on the question, which has been argued at great length. I suggested some amendments in the clause, entirely with the view of meeting objections that had been outlined at an earlier stage; but I find that my attempt at amendment is treated with the utmost disdain and scorn. I am now told that I have made the thing infinitely worse than before, which is, of course, most unsatisfactory for me, and, apparently, worse for the Committee. The honorable member for Maranoa spoke about the position of persons with pastoral holdings which are subject to a depreciation of value owing to droughts. A man always knows what the value of his land is. If his land is worth very little, he will put down a very small amount in his return. If it is worth a lot, he will put that down'. After the drought of 1893 had gone over this country, the honorable member knew to within a little what his own property was worth. It may have been worth only one-fifth of what it was before the drought came; but, whatever it was, he knew it. Let him, therefore, put that down in the assessment paper.
- It is not the ground that is of value to the pastoralist ; it is the grass and water. That is the only asset he has.

- That argument applies to all classes of land. The value of land used for agricultural or pastoral purposes depends entirely on the extent to which it meets those purposes. If you cannot get any grass on land on which you are running sheep, you have to feed them or drive them off. The question is, what is. the position of the owner of land in those circumstances? If a man has a piece of land, and a drought comes, and he has no grass, the capital value of the land is depreciated ; but he knows it, and nobody knows it better than he does. He can say, " My land is not worth one-tenth of what it was five years ago." There may be plenty of cases where that applies. We are only asking the owner to say what his land is worth. I know many cases where, during drought 5'ears, if a man could have got 10 per cent, above his own valuation, he would have been the happiest man in creation, and glad of the chance to unload his estate. I have never yet known a case where a big squatter or pastoral owner was not influenced by one of two things. Either he had confidence that the present was a mere passing phase, and that good times would come again, or he had abandoned all hope and was seeking to unload. If he is seeking to unload, this is the best chance he has; because he has only to put his own valuation on the land, and we will give him 10 per cent, more for it. The honorable member for Maranoa has stated that we desire to do justice. I hope we all have that desire, however our views may differ as to the means. There is, I know, a strong desire on the part of honorable members on this side to do justice; and one of the most effective refutations of the ridiculous statements that are made from time to time in the press, and by some members on the other side, that those on this side come here with their minds made up, and have no opinions of their own, is to be found in the fact that criticism of amendments put forward by the Government comes quite as frequently from this side as from that. I am prepared to strike out the word " wilfully," from subparagraph ii., of paragraph c, and then to retain the sub-paragraph. That will, I think, meet most of the objections urged against the clause, .and is going as far as, and perhaps a little further than, I ought to go. I have no other desire than to protect the revenue, and compel people to realize that it is a very serious thing to undervalue their land without some good cause. If that amendment will meet the wishes of the Committee, I am prepared to consider it. If the honorable member for Angas will withdraw his amendment, I shall move my prior amendments, and then move to amend sub-paragraph ii., as I stated.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - - I d° not see that the proposal made by the Attorney-General will make any great difference. The AttorneyGeneral has described the amendment of the honorable member for Angas as practically a " disembowelment " of the Bill.
- I did not say that at all !

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - I think "disembowelment" was the word used.
- It does not follow that "disembowelment" attached to the amendment ; I said there were some people who wished to disembowel the whole measure.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - I understood the application of the term to be to the amendment; but, at any fate, if the clause is passed without that amendment, it will practically amount to a " metaphorical disembowelment " of the landowner. The honorable member for Maranoa has told us that the Attorney-General only desires to "rope in" those who are dishonest; and we give the AttorneyGeneral credit for that desire. But that is exactly what is asked by honorable members on this side, who support the amendment of the honorable member for Angas.
- Then the suggested amendment of the Attorney-General ought to suit honorable members opposite!

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - The suggested amendment does not meet the case so effectually as that proposed by the honorable member for Angas. Honorable members have expressed a desire not to unduly penalize or harshly deal with any persons under this Bill; and the suggestion that this is a step in the direction of land nationalization has also been mildly repudiated. But if we are to accept all those statements as sincere, our obvious duty is to support the amendment of the honorable member for Angas, which aims only at justice being preserved. It has been pointed out that the clause as it stands, or even as amended in the way suggested by the Attorney-General, will still have the effect of unduly penalizing many landowners who, in perfect good faith, may send in a return undervaluing his land to the extent of even more than 25 per cent. Under the clause as we have it, such landowners are not only liable to have their land compulsorily purchased, but are subject to further drastic penalties under another portion of the Bill. Under the circumstances, we ought to seriously consider the advisability of accepting the amendment of the honorable member for Angas, which makes the clause apply only to those persons who wilfully undervalue their land for the purpose of evading taxation. Surely the mere fact that a person may innocently make an undervaluation should not subject him to the drastic penalties provided?
- Does the honorable member think that evasion of the taxation will not be wilful?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - Not necessarilyso in all cases, but if the undervaluation is for the purpose of evading taxation, it is dishonest.
- That is all we mean.

speech.para: Mr.W. ELLIOT JOHNSON. - And that is what the amendment provides for.

talk.start.para: - So does the clause.
- The only difference is that the onus of proof is changed.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: JOHNSON, Elliot
Mr W ELLIOT JOHNSON

talk.start.para: - The amendment of the honorable member for Angas is better. Evidence should be given to show deliberate intention on the part of a land-owner to undervalue his land for the purpose of evading taxation; and, if that is the desire of the Attorney-General and other honorable members opposite, I call their attention to the fact that ft is what the amendment of the honorable member for Angas secures. Assuming that we have the right to impose land taxation, I am just as eager as honorable members opposite to see that there is no intentional evasion; but I am also anxious that no injustice shall be done to a person who innocently happens to make a mistake.

.- I am at a loss to know why honorable members opposite do not accept the suggestion of the Attorney-General. That honorable gentleman has made a concession which, personally, I do not favour, but, inasmuch as honorable members opposite have urged that the proposed conditions are not strictly equitable, he is driven to meet them; and, when he does so, they continue to urge that the amendment of the honorable member for Angas should be adopted.
- I have not said a word myself yet.

- I fail to see the consistency of honorable members opposite. The honorable member for Parramatta raved as usual about the injustice perpetrated on the land-owner, but the records will show that honorable members on this side who have had to deal with land-owners and their interest have always acted justly. It is an insult to infer that we are here for the purpose of persecuting men who are on the land; we are here in order to pass an equitable and effective measure of land taxation. If honorable members opposite had their own way, this land taxation would not be effective - just as it failed in New Zealand, and there required amendment on the lines suggested by the AttorneyGeneral. The honorable member for Maranoa has talked about the injustice heaped on the man in the western districts of Queensland j but he must know that in the north-west of New South Wales, and the portion of Queensland to which he referred, the lands are under leasehold, and will not come within the operation of the Bill. Even assuming that there are some lessees who have the right of purchase, and who may come under the Bill, what is the value of their land in drought-stricken areas? Does the honorable member mean to tell me that values are going up and down according to how the rain falls?
- The AttorneyGeneral told us so, anyhow !
- I do not care what the Attorney-General or anybody else said !
- Hear, hear ! The honorable member is a great authority !

- Anyhow, I claim to be as great an authority as the honorable member is. Pastoral land is assessed, not on the annual producing power, but on the average producing power ; all the disabilities are taken into consideration. In the shire assessments such a liberal allowance is made for the prevailing conditions that the difference between the assessed value and the actual value in the market is very striking.
- Does the honorable member mean leasehold land ?
- I mean either leasehold or freehold.
- The shires are obliged to make a statutory valuation of the leasehold land.
- I do not care what the shires are "obliged" to make - I tell the honorable member the valuation they do make.
- That valuation is twenty times the annual rental.

- In the district I represent I have seen land assessed by the shire councils at £2 per acre, and I have seen that land subdivided and sold at auction, the lowest block at £4 10s., and the highest at £9. That represents the prevailing conditions in regard to shire- assessment throughout the north-western por tion of New South Wales, and there is no justification for the statement of the honorable member for Parramatta that overassessment is the common rule.
- The honorable member has quoted only one case.
- Surely the honorable member does not desire me to occupy time by quoting a whole list of cases. Any ordinary, sensible man would take a concrete case as representing the conditions.
- An ordinary, sensible man would do just the contrary !
- Men like the honorable member for Parramatta would make this Bill, absolutely ineffective if they could.
- Abuse, as usual !

- The honorable member would so frame this measure as to leave loopholes big enough for a motor car to drive through. I warn the AttorneyGeneral that the party behind the Government has a mandate from the people to impose a land tax which shall effectively apply to those who should be called on to pay it, and that it is our duty to see that Ministers do not in a weak moment yield to the wiles of the Opposition, and its appeals for sympathy for the man on the land. The honorable member for Parramatta and others have referred to the penalties in another part of the Bill as if they were sufficient, although those honorable members know that those penalties do not cover the set of conditions provided for by the clause. The object of the clause is to prevent men from wilfully undervaluing their land, the Government being permitted, where an owner has sought in this way to evade legitimate taxation, to acquire his property for the good of the people. That is a fair provision. In New South Wales to-day, when land is resumed by the Government, and a Board of Arbitration is appointed to determine its value, a mass of interested evidence is submitted, with a view to increasing the price which the Government has to pay. Men are always ready to inflate values when the Government wishes to buy, and to undervalue when the Government intends to tax. Our duty is to see that fair taxation is paid, and to prevent the evasion of just responsibilities. No doubt, honorable members opposite are ready to insert in the Bill provisions which would render it useless, and would do harm to the party responsible for it. I am with the Attorney-General in regard to the striking out of the word " wilfully " in sub-paragraph ii. of paragraph c, though after what has taken place this afternoon, I shall watch carefully the proposals of the Opposition.

. - According to the honorable member for Gwydir, land should be valued, not on the basis of its production in the year of valuation, but on its average productivity ; whereas, according to the honorable member for Maranoa, a man valuing after a series of droughts might make his valuation too low, and after a series of good seasons might make it too high. The Attorney-General seems to think that if land had decreased in value by the time that the valuation was called for, the owner would be justified in writing down the value, and that the Government would accept such a valuation. These differences of opinion show the difficulty of determining the unimproved value of land. The Attorney-General defended the proposal before the Committee by referring to the section in the Customs Act under which, if an importer has wilfully and grossly undervalued goods liable to ad valorem duty, the Government may take them at an advance of 10 per cent, on the valuation; but it must be remembered that, while it is possible for an honest importer to prove his bona fides and the value of the goods, it is never possible to prove the unimproved value of land, there being always land, even in suburban areas, whose value it is very difficult to get at. To show that valuations may honestly vary beyond the 25 per cent, margin provided for, let me instance my own experience. Within recent years I have bought land in three of the suburbs of Sydney. Within the Kurringai Chase shire, I have 100 acres which is notoriously overvalued, notwithstanding the statement of the honorable member for Gwydir that shire councils invariably undervalue. The New South Wales Act restricts shire councils to a rate of 2d. in tlie £1 on the unimproved value of land within their boundaries; but as that did not give a sufficient revenue in the Kurringm Chase shire, values there were deliberately inflated, with the consent of the taxpayers of the shire. Were I to value my land there for the purposes of this Bill, I should fix a much lower value than that on which the shire levied its rates. I have other land at Bondi, in the Waverley municipality, which I bought for ^720, and which within two months afterwards the council valued at over £1,000.
- Was it bought at a forced sst lc ?

- No; the holding in question consists of five or six allotments bought at auction. Were I valuing the land for the purposes of the Bill, I should declare the valuation to be ,£720, which is what I paid for it ; but if the Government accepted the municipal valuation, which is more than 25 per cent, higher, my land would be liable to forfeiture, although my valuation was given in perfect good faith.
- Would not the Court take that into consideration?

- The clause does not provide for that being done. I have another block of land on the Narrabeen Lagoon, which I purchased for 17s. 6d. a foot, and for which I was offered £2 a foot immediately afterwards. Were I to value that land for the purposes of the tax at tlie price which I gave for it, the valuation would, no doubt, be accepted, but I should be giving an undervaluation. We are making a mistake in asking the owners of land to value it when, if we are to have a national system of land taxation, we should have a national system of land valuation.
- How long would it be, then, before the tax could be levied ?

- It could not be levied before the 30th June next. But we might get an honest assessment which would serve as the basis of future State or municipal assessments. According to the honorable member for Gwydir, some of the shire councils and municipalities undervalue. That is true of Tasmania, and to a large extent of Victoria, but it is notoriously untrue of New South Wales, where many of the municipalities have very much overvalued their lands.
- The shire councils have not overvalued.

- We are dealing with the whole of the lands of Australia. Provisions like those in the clause will do gross injustice. The work of valuation should not fall on the landowners. The Government should make an independent valuation, and preserve to the owners the right of appeal. The honorable member for Gwydir is quite wrong in thinking that that would necessarily mean a three years' postponement.
- I ask the honorable member not to discuss the question of assessments.
- The honorable member is only wasting time. He is simply " spinning " out the debate until the adjournment for dinner.
- I am no more wasting time than the Attorney-General is. I am dealing with the question on its merits.
- The honorable member has been dealing with a matter that has no relation to the question before the Chair.

- The honorable gentleman is no judge of the question of relevancy. I am endeavouring to show that the Attorney-General's proposed amendment will act with great injustice on many people, and I am suggesting an alternative. The Attorney-General's desire is to push this clause through Committee, within three minutes of the adjournment for dinner. I do not care whether he does or does not. For my part, he could have had the whole Bill a fortnight ago, for it will do the Government no good. The proposed alteration will not improve the working of the Bill, but I leave it to the Government to do what they can with it.

.- I am prepared to accept as an improvement upon the original proposals of the AttorneyGeneral, the proposition now made by him. I do not think that the omission of the word " wilfully " will make any difference, but if the honorable gentleman thinks it will, I have no objection to its being left out. When we come to clause 65, we may endeavour to shift the burden of proof from the owner to the Government. Meantime, will the Attorney-General consider whether it would not be better to strike out that clause? The question of resumption where forfeiture will result is not to be raised by an undervaluation of less than 25 per cent. I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

quote.para: That after the word " land," line 5, the words "to the extent of 25 per centum or more" be inserted.
That after the word " land," line 19, the words " to the extent of 25 per centum or more," be inserted.
That the word "wilfully," line 21, be left out.

speech.para: Mr. JOSEPHCOOK (Parramatta) peal to the Attorney-General to forego this provision altogether?

talk.start.para: - I cannot agree to do that.
- It seems to me to be an excrescence on the Bill, and altogether foreign to an ordinary taxation measure. I do not know why it has been inserted.

quote.para: That the following words be added to paragraph e - " together with the amount of 10 per centum upon that improved value, by way of an allowance for compulsory dispossession."

talk.start.para: .- I am not sure that I understand the effect of this amendment. I think it would be better if the words "10 per centum " were not qualified by the words, " by way of an allowance for compulsory dispossession," because, in the next paragraph, we to a great extent incorporate in this clause, the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act of 1906. If I am not mistaken, there are in that Act provisions for compensation for the compulsory taking of land, so that the effect of these words would be to make the addition of 10 per cent.cover all allowances for compulsory acquisition. We may, therefore, be cutting down to some extent the effect of the incorporation of the Lands Acquisition Act.
- Is not 10 per cent. sufficient ?

- I think that there ought to be an addition without any remission of compensation. This amount of 10 per cent. should simply be a margin given by the Commissioner to cover the possibility of his making an error of valuation. It is quite a different thing to say that this 10 per cent. is to be a sort of commutation of the amount to which a man would be entitled under the Lands Acquisition Act of 1906.
- I see the honorable member's point and will look into it.
. - There is a misunderstanding, Mr. Chairman. We understood that we were proceeding to a division on clause 44.
- The Chairman put the question that the call for a division be withdrawn, and it was agreed to.
- And the honorable member for Angas, who made the call, withdrew it.

quote.para: The following provisions shall apply in any case where, whether intentionally or not, a taxpayer escapes full taxation in his lifetime by reason of not having duly made full and complete returns : - (a)The Commissioner shall have the same powers and remedies against the executors and administrators of the taxpayer as he would have had against the taxpayer in his lifetime.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The assessment shall be at the rates payable in respect of the years for which the tax ought to have been paid, and the amount payable shall be treble the amount of the difference between the tax so assessed and the amount actually paid by the taxpayer, and shall be a first charge on all the taxpayer's estate.

talk.start.para: - On a point of order, Mr. Chairman, I submit that a division ought to have been taken on clause 44.
- That point of order cannot be taken on clause 49.

- We are not properly dealing with clause 49. The question, " That clause 44 as amended be agreed to," was put to the Committee, and those voting with the " noes " took their places on this side of the chamber. There was no opportunity of hearing what you were saying. Every honorable member sitting on this side fully believed that we were proceeding to a division on clause 44, and it would be a denial of justice to the Opposition to allow this clause by misadventure to be passed without a division.I venture to say that no one on this side was aware that you had passed from clause 44 to other clauses. Some one has said that the call for a division was withdrawn. I could understand an honorable member, who had moved an amendment, withdrawing a call for a division uponit; but we were dealing with a clause in respect of which every honorable member had an interest and a right to demand a division. The great bulk of us were totally unaware of what was being done by you. We shall suffer a denial of justice unless you enable us, sir, to have our votes recorded on a clause on which we desired to divide.

- On the point of order, I would like to explain that before we adjourned for dinner, it was agreed that we should have a division on clause 44. When the question was put, a few minutes ago, " That the clause as amended be agreed to," several honorable members of the Opposition cried, "Divide." I was amongst the number. I wished to go to a division, but at least five or six honorable members on this side said that they did not. The result was that, although neither I nor any one else that I know of asked that the call for a division should be withdrawn, the Chairman himself, from what was said, thought that there was a withdrawal of the call. I do not think the question was properly put.
- I put it.

- The question might have been put again, and then the voices would have been taken one way or the other, but there was some confusion as to what really occurred after that point. In justice to the Chairman as well as to members on the other side, I must say that at least five members particularly asked the honorable member for Darling Downs and myself not to take a division on the question, although it had been arranged before the tea hour that there was to be a division.

- Upon the Chairman putting the question " that the clause as amended stand part of the Bill," those on this side cried "Aye," and the honorable member for Darling Downs and the honorable member for Angas cried " No," whereupon the Chairman directed that a division should be taken. The bells were rung, the honorable member for Balaclava and others came in, and went over near where the honorable member for Angas was sitting. I think the honorable member for Parramatta was also there or thereabouts. I said, " I have amended the clause to suit you, and now you call for a division." I was addressing my remarks more particularly to the honorable member for Balaclava across the table, and he said " No division," or words to that effect. The Chairman then said, " Is it the pleasure of the Committee that the call for a division be withdrawn?" or words, to that effect. The Chairman understood, and I understood, that it was withdrawn, and I am sure honorable members on this side were under the impression that there was to be no division. It did not matter to this side whether a division was taken or not, but when, through some blunder or misunderstanding on the other side, honorable members sitting there do not get what they want, it is of no use for them to blame the Government or the Chairman. In the circumstances, no further time ought to be lost. Honorable members on the other side have made their protest, and the position is clear.

- I came into the chamber to vote, and was sitting here waiting for the vote to be taken. When I asked why it was not being taken, I was told that the Attorney-General had called the division off, and I could not understand that. The Chairman evidently put the matter while the confusion was on.
- No blame attaches to any one.
- No; except that it is the invariable practice in Parliament, where there has been a mistake, to rectify the matter.

- When the clause as amended was put, there were voices on both sides, and I said, " The Committee will now divide." The glass was turned up, and in a little while a discussion took place in this corner, and I clearly heard the remark " No division." I then said, in a clear voice, "Is it the pleasure of the Committee that the call for a division be withdrawn?" and there was no objection to that. I then proceeded with the next clause.
- We did not hear you.
- I cannot go backnow.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - I watched the whole affair, and I think the Attorney-General has given a very correct statement of what took place, but a large number of members on this side, in consequence of the noise in the chamber, did not know what you were doing. They have been deprived of their right to a division which they wished to insist upon, and which they would have had if you, Mr. Chairman, had known their feelings.

- I submit that, under the Standing Orders, it is impossible to go back. Those sitting on this side of the House, Mr. Chairman, distinctly recollect hearing those on the other side of the House, who had called for a division, withdraw that call. We also clearly heard the Chairman ask whether it was the pleasure of the Committee that the call should be withdrawn, and it was withdrawn. During that time, or immediately afterwards, a number of honor able members who- sit on the other side of the House came in. They were not in the chamber when the call 'was withdrawn. Three clauses have been passed since then, and, in the circumstances, it is impossible to go back.

- I wish to make a personal explanation, as I may be primarily responsible for the difficulty that has arisen. When the last amendment was proposed by the Attorney-General some honorable members called out " No," and I went up to the honorable member foi Angas and the honorable member for Darling Downs, and suggested that there should not be a division on it. I understood that the division was being called foi on an amendment in paragraph e of clause 44, and I called out " No division." I did not know that you had directed a division to be taken on the clause itself. I thought it was on the amendment. I, therefore, take any responsibility there is for any mistake that has happened ; but it would be only reasonable to allow those who wished to do so an opportunity of voting against the clause.

- It ought to meet the wish of the Committee if honorable members will agree to divide on the clause without discussion, when it is reached in its turn on the recommittal of the Bill. I am prepared to arrange for that.

- I wish to make a personal explanation. I did not object to the withdrawal of the division on clause 44, hut I did not hear you put the question that it should be withdrawn, nor, on account of the noise, did I hear you putting the subsequent clauses. I had a small amendment to move on clause 46, but have had no opportunity of proposing it. There seems to have been a misunderstanding for which nobody is to blame. It was caused by the disorder in the Committee. We ought to have some opportunity of testing the whole of the clauses that have since been put. I should be very pleased if the Attorney-General would agree to recommit clause 46. His offer to recommit clause 44 will not do what I require, as that matter has been threshed out, and I did not care very much whether we divided on it or not, as I knew we should lose on a division.
- I said that I would take a vote on clause 44 on recommittal, if it were agreed that there should be no discussion. I shall do the same with clause 46, if that will suit the honorable member.
- I ask for that to be done.

- I desire to raise a question of privilege. These matters are not for the Attorney-General alone to decide, but involve the question of order in the Committee. The clauses have been put through by you, Mr. Chairman, when there has been such disorder in the Committee as prevented honorable members from hearing what was going on. The disorder is nothing unusual, as it occurs during every division, and I submit that the proper thing to do is to secure order before business is dealt with. It is not right to have these matters rushed through, when no one knows what is going on.
- Whose fault is it?

- I do not want to say whose fault it is ; but I respectfully submit that the Chairman should see that order is restored before he puts a clause. It has been the invariable rule of Parliament that, when the Chairman's attention has been called to anything of this kind, he should put the question over again. That is a simple way out.

- I rise to order. There was so much noise and confusionthat I was shocked when it was ascertained that the division was not being proceeded with on clause 44, and that the subsequent clauses had been actually put without my hearing them, or realizing what was being done. They were all put while the discussion was going on as to whether there should or should not be a division on clause 44. I strongly object to such a drastic clause, on which there was so much criticism and difference of opinion, being allowed to go through without a division simply because some one, thinking the division was on an amendment, called " No division." Every one of us most strongly objects to clause 44.
- The honorable member will have an opportunity to vote against it.

- But it seems to me that there ought to be an opportunity now. In hundreds of cases of error or misunderstanding the question has been put again ; and I cannot understand the Government not assisting in placing every member in his proper position for or against the clause. I feel that I have not recorded my opinion against a provision which I regard as one of the most unconstitutional and improper in the whole Bill.

- Do I understand that the Attorney-General is going to allow an opportunity for the discussion of clause 46? It is not worth my while to simply vote on the clause, because I desire to move an amendment. I have been told that the only promise given is that we shall have an opportunity to vote.
- The honorable member may move his amendment, provided there is no discussion.
- Will the AttorneyGeneral promise to recommit the clause ?

speech.para: Mr. HUGHES(West Sydney- Acting Prime Minister and Attorney-General [8.28J. - I have said so. I move -

quote.para: That after the word " taxpayer," where first occurring in paragraph a, the words " in respect of the estate of the taxpayer " be inserted.

speech.para: This amendment is to limit the scope of the Commissioner's powers in cases where the estate is being administered by administrators or an executor, as the case may be.

talk.start.para: .- The amendment just passed was clearly necessary, because we did not in the beginning declare that trustees are acting in their representative capacity, and, as in every other taxation measure, that they could not be liable beyond the value of the estate. We have now to get rid of another anomaly. Under this clause, if a mistake has been .made by a person deceased, whether intentionally or not, the executors are to be mulct in treble the amount of the tax ; and that is very unfair. A dead person cannot, of course, be called as a witness; and yet, for an act which may not have been wilful, his executors are punished as though it had been wilful. By a subsequent clause, if a man wilfully evades taxation there is the penalty of treble the amount; and that is very fair, because the taxpayer is alive to reply to the charge. ,But such a penalty is not fair in the case of executors, seeing that the only person who could explain that an omission was not wilful cannot give evidence. I suggest that the words " shall be treble the amount of the difference between the tax so assessed and the amount actually paid by the taxpayer and " be struck out. This simply means that' in the case of evasion during the lifetime of the taxpayer, his execetors shall be liable lo the full extent of the tax had the evasion not taken place. As a matter of fact, I do not believe that any harm would be done if the clause were altogether omitted, first because there is always a remedy against the estate, and, secondly, the remedy inures against the executors and administrators. There is no need for the clause except to accomplish something that is bad, namely, the apparent desire of the draftsman to impose a fine of treble the amount of the tax.

. - The suggestion of the honorable member creates a sensible distinction between the estate of a deceased person and the estate of a living one. We cannot convict a dead man of having wilfully done anything; and, therefore, the words at the head of the clause, "whether intentionally or not," seem very appropriate to the circumstances. The honorable member says that the estate ought not to be taxed to treble the amount of the difference, which is one of the penalties set forth in clause 65. If the honorable member will allow me to consider the matter and see how far we can safely go, I shall do so in the light of his remarks.
- I accept that assurance.

. - Paragraph d provides that no lapse of time shall prevent the operation of the clause. It will be impossible for trustees to wind up estates in land unless there is some means of obtaining a certificate from the Commissioner that he has no claim. If the trustees distribute an estate with the chance of a charge of this kind, they will be liable either to the Crown or to the beneficiaries. There certainly ought to be limit of time of, say, one or two years. Under the State Act of Victoria, trustees, before they proceed to distribute, must advertise in certain newspapers and in the Government Gazette that on and after a certain date they are going to do so; and in this clause there is no provision to protect them in any way. Under the circumstances, I do not know how trustees are to close an estate in land, because, it may be, ten years afterwards the question could arise whether in any preceding year the estate had been undervalued.
- Is the honorable member speaking of the liability of the trustees, or of the liability of persons who buy the trust estate?

- If this is a; charge on the land, then the people who buy are in a difficulty; but what I am pointing out is that the trustees, unless they have a certificate, will not be able to distribute an estate, seeing that before doing so they have to satisfy all claims. A charge should only be on the land until it is parted with, because a purchaser will have to ask if there is any charge on it, and no trustee can prove that there has not been undervaluation, and great difficulty will thereby be caused in conveyancing. Unless some alteration is made in the clause, there will be much complication without any special good resulting. The Commissioner should be able to determine within twelve months whether land has been properly valued.

. - By way of reply to the honorable member for Balaclava, let me say that, so far as a trustee is concerned, once an estate has been distributed, his liability ceases. As for those who acquire trust estates, it is proposed to amend clause 52 in a way which will meet their case. -The clause contains the proviso that no charge for land tax shall be of effect as against a bond fide purchaser for value who, at the time of purchase made due inquiry, but had no notice of the liability. I propose to amend the clause by adding a further proviso to the effect that persons shall be deemed to have made due inquiry who have made inquiry of the Commissioner. The man who buys bond fide and for value land which has formed part of a trust estate, or any other land, will not, if he has made due inquiry, that is, inquiry of the Commissioner as prescribed, be liable for the tax. The tax is a charge in rem, and not in personam, and therefore a trustee's liability will be extinguished once he has got rid of the trust estate.
. - If a man sells land, and after his death it is discovered that he evaded taxation in regard to it, will the estate in the hands of his executors, supposing it is wholly personalty, be liable?
- If the honorable member will look at clauses 44 to 49 he will see that the tax is a debt, and recoverable as such.

- Is the Attorney-General satisfied that he has power, in a measure of this kind, to create a charge on the personal estate left by a man who evaded payment of taxation in respect of land which he afterwards sold?
- I am satisfied that we have the right to recover the money owing to us in respect of the tax.

- The honorable member for Balaclava has shown that the clause may create serious difficulty in regard to trust estates, because there is no limitation against recovery. I hope that the AttorneyGeneral will look into the matter. If he is satisfied that, when a trust estate has been distributed, the trustee, being functus officio, has no further liability, that meets one objection raised.
- A trustee's personal liability is extinguished with the distribution of the trust estate.

. - I am pleased that the Attorney-General intends to move an amendment for the protection of bona fide purchasers for value. I would point out, however, that if the proceeds of an estate are in the hands of trustees, they will be unable to part with them until they get a certificate from the Commissioner that they have no liability in respect of the tax, and he is not bound to give such a certificate. If the AttorneyGeneral would agree to an amendment similar to that proposed by the honorable member for Gippsland, enabling trustees to compel the Commissioner to give a certificate, that would probably meet the case. After the distribution of an estate creditors ran file a suit in equity and follow the assets into the hands of the persons to whom they have been distributed, and if trustees in an estate in which three of the beneficiaries lived in Australia, and the remaining five abroad, distributed the estate, the portions of the Australian beneficiaries could be taxed, but those of the beneficiaries living abroad could not be, which would be unfair. Either there should be a limit of time, or the Commissioner should be compelled to give a certificate.

quote.para: No statute of limitations at any time in force shall bar or affect any action or remedy for recovery of land tax.

talk.start.para: . - I should like the Attorney-General to provide some limitation, such as is fixed in regard to legal rights generally. After the lapse of years it will be very difficult to obtain evidence as to the unimproved value of land.
- The tax being a charge on the land, would there not be a limitation of twelve or fifteen years?
- The Attorney-General might take into consideration the rules in regard to real estate, with a view to determining whether it is advisable not to have a limitation.
- I shall look into the matter.

speech.para: Clause 51 (Remedy against other persons where taxpayer makes default).

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That the following words be added to the clause : - " Provided that the responsibility of the lessee or occupier under this section shall only be to the extent of any rent or payments due by him to the taxpayer at the time of demand made or action brought by the Commissioner, or from time to time accruing due thereafter."

speech.para: This proviso is of a far-reaching character, and will have the effect of limiting the liability of the lessee or occupier to the amount of rent due or payable by him to the taxpayer.

talk.start.para: . - I had made a note of an. amendment to the same effect, which I intended to move; and I welcome the ample way in which the AttorneyGeneral has dealt with this matter. There is an addition which the AttorneyGeneral might consider. Under the clause as it stands, there is no provision for notice to the lessee that there are arrears of taxation. The clause provides that where a taxpayer makes default, there shall be a remedy against the lessee to the extent of any money payable by him to the taxpayer that may still be in his hands. He might part with those moneys ; but I think that the liability would still remain. It is only fair that he should get notice from the Commissioner that his landlord - the taxpayer - has not paid the tax. There is a provision to that effect, if I remember rightly, in the South Australian Act; and I suggest that after the word "occupier," the words " one mouth's personal notice by the Commissioner," be inserted.
- Very well. I will look into the matter.

speech.para: Clause 52 - (1.) Land tax shall until payment be a first charge upon the land taxed in priority over all other encumbrances whatever, and notwithstanding any disposition of the land it shall continue to be liable in the hands of any purchaser or holder for the payment of the tax so long as it remains unpaid :

quote.para: Provided that no such charge shall be of effect as against a bond fide purchaser for value who at the time of purchase made clue inquiry but had no notice of the liability. (2.) Where the Commissioner thinks it advisable to register the charge, he may lodge with the Registrar-General or Registrar of Titles or other proper officer of the State or part of the Commonwealth in which the land is situated a certificate under his hand describing the land charged, and stating that there are arrears of land tax payable in respect thereof ; and the Registrar or other proper officer shall register it in the register and as nearly as may be in the manner in which dealings with land are registered, and shall deal with and give effect to the certificate as if it were an instrument of charge or incumbrance duly executed under the laws in force in that State or part of the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: . - This clause declares that the tax is to be a first charge upon the land taxed ; that it is to have priority over all other encumbrances, and that, notwithstanding any disposition of the land, it shall continue to be liable, in the hands of any purchaser, for the payment of the tax, so long as that tax remains unpaid. The proviso exempts a bond fide purchaser for value who, at the time of purchase, makes due inquiry, but has no notice of liability. That, in substance, repeats the terms of the Real Property Act of New South Wales; but a doubt arises as to what is " due inquiry." The honorable member for Gippsland has given notice of an amendment dealing with the point, and the honorable member for Angas has also done so. I shall ask the Committee to agree to the clause with a further amendment providing -

quote.para: That the following words be added-" Provided further that a purchaser shall be deemed to have made due inquiry who has made inquiry of the Commissioner as prescribed."

speech.para: That, I think,- will meet the case fully; and no bond fide purchaser need be in any doubt as to his liability for unpaid land tax. In substance, I think the amendment will achieve the object at which the honorable member for Gippsland aims ; and I ask the Committee to accept it.

talk.start.para: .- 1 have given notice of a prior amendment which, I think, ought to be inserted. I propose to move -

quote.para: That after the word " liability " at the end of the proviso, as printed, the words " or after the expiration of six months from the date on which the tax became due and payable, unless registered under sub-section 2 of this section," be inserted.

speech.para: The effect of my amendment would be that, unless the Commissioner, six months after the tax became payable, and, consequently, a charge upon the land, registered that charge in the State in which the land was situated, the charge would not remain. That would overcome the difficulty pointed out by the honorable member for Balaclava. We are dealing with Federal conditions, and it would be rather hard on a person selling land in a distant State to be obliged to write to the Department at the Seat of Government to ascertain what charges under the Land Tax Assessment Act remained unpaid. We have one of the most expeditious systems of land transfer in the world, and we ought not to impose any obstacle to the prompt transfer of property. I pointed out to an English visitor within the last twenty-four hours that a big transaction in real estate might be settled here, and the transfer given, within two hours, as long as the parties could get to the Registrar's office and ascertain whether there were any registered charges or notices of trusts. If a man happened to be transferring land in Western Australia, and had to write to the Seat of Government to obtain information as to the non-payment of land taxation, there might be a- delay of a month in obtaining a transfer, and I think that such an amendment as I have stated should be accepted. In the next sub-clause it is provided that the Commissioner may register such a charge; and that shows that it is considered that it will be possible for him to make the necessary arrangements to have it registered. I do not feel strongly on this question, but I think that such an amendment as I have indicated would meet the wishes of the Committee. My object is to see that land transactions are not delayed owing to unregistered charges of the Government resting upon property.

talk.start.para: .- An amendment has just occurred to me in consequence of a suggestion made by the honorable member for Balaclava. It illustrates one of the many difficulties that arise in connexion with legislation of this kind. This clause purports to impose the land tax as a first charge upon the land, in priority to all other encumbrances. In some of the State Acts various charges are made a first charge upon the land. In Victoria, for instance, the expenses incurredby the Government in grants for wire netting are so treated.
- And the State land tax is made a first charge.
- I was not quite sure of that.
- Rates are also made a charge upon the land.

- By Act of Parliament they are made a first charge. We shall thus have two competing first charges. Which is to prevail ? The Constitution provides that where a law of the Commonwealth is inconsistent with the law of a State the Commonwealth law shall prevail ; but that has no reference whatever to a proposal of this kind. If the Commonwealth had the power to make laws creating, for instance, first charges upon the lands of the Commonwealth, then, of course, anything that the Commonwealth Parliament declared to be a first charge upon the land would take priority over anything which a State declared to be a first charge upon it.
- Is that not so at the present time?
- No; we have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to taxation.
- Does not that power apply in this case?

- We have power to make laws with regard to taxation, and necessary incidental powers relating to taxation; but a power to destroy existing charges created by a State is not incidental to the general power of taxation. I suggest to the Attorney-General that, if he wishes to remove one more of the constitutional difficulties with which this Bil bristles, it might be well for him to insert after the words " first charge," the words "subject to any charge created under the legislative authority of a State, and in existence at the time at which the land tax becomes payable," or words to that effect.
- The honorable member suggests that we should subordinate our powers to those of the States?

- The honorable member knows that no one is less willing than I am to subordinate our powers to those of the States; but that should not prevent us from endeavouring to define our powers, and to refrain from usurping powers that we do not really possess This would not be a law inconsistent with the law of a State. It would be a law inconsistent with an existing charge created under State law, which the State had .per fect authority to make. If the AttorneyGeneral insists upon making this a first charge upon land, it would be just as well to remove that constitutional difficulty.

. - The amendment of -the honorable and learned member for Angas seems to render the whole intention of the clause entirely inoperative, or to hamstring it. It would have the effect of limiting the liability in respect of any land to six months. If the Commissioner did not know it within that time, and he could not register it unless he did know it, the land would escape liability. I do not think the amendment is right, or in any way necessary. The amend- v... _ ment I suggested, that a person should be deemed to have made due inquiry who has made inquiry of the Commissioner as prescribed and been told by him that there is no charge, should be quite sufficient. I come now to the suggestion of the honorable member for Flinders, who seems to doubt either the wisdom or the right of this Parliament to make its land tax a first charge upon land, because there are other charges in various States. No doubt that is perfectly true. This will not destroy those charges. If we make the tax a first charge on the land, it will be a first charge, and all that will happen will be that, if other existing first charges come in conflict with it, they will be postponed. That is eminently proper. Does the honorable member suggest that we should postpone our right until the State right has been satisfied? I cannot agree to that.

- - I do not think the Attorney-General quite heard my argument. If a first charge has been created on land in favour qf a State, that first charge is the property of the State. If we impose another first charge which takes priority of that, it becomes a first charge, not only on the whole of the land, but on the State's first charge, and therefore a charge upon the property of the State. That manifestly we cannot do. There is no use in our attempting to put in a Statute tilings which we cannot do. We have no more right to impose this tax as a charge upon the State's charge on land than to impose it upon any other portion of the property of a State.
- Does the honorable member doubt the effect of the phraseology of the clause to impose a first charge?

- Surely the AttorneyGeneral understands the position clearly. A piece of land may have as many encumbrances on it as you like. So long as they are made by the owner in favour of private individuals, this Parliament can impose a land tax as a first charge or. the land in priority to any or all of them, but this Parliament has no power to impose a land tax or anything else as a first charge in priority to a legally established first charge to a State, which is the State's property. Take an extreme case. Suppose that the charge in favour of the State was so great as to absorb the value of the land. Then that land in reality belongs to the State, and we are attempting verbally to say that we put a first charge, on that land in priority to the charge of the State, which we have no power to do. . 11 we attempt to make our tax a first charge in priority to all other encumbrances, weought at least to prevent the clause being altogether unconstitutional by making it subject to that to which it must be subject - namely, the existing property of the State in that land.

speech.para: Mr.Webster. - If the State subsequently decided to take all the value of the property, it would leave the Commonwealth none at all.

talk.start.para: - The Parliament of a State may, subsequently to the passing of this Act, create a first charge, in the exercise of its legislative authority, for any purpose it likes in favour of itself. If it does so, it exercises the same function as if it took a portion or the whole of that land compulsorily. The land becomes its property. We can, however, make a law saying that, until the State has made any land its property, and has therefore taken it out of the domain that we can touch, we impose a charge upon the land.
- Then, if a State imposed a land tax, and made it a first charge, we could not enforce ours at all ?

- Not to take priority of the State's charge. We could give it priority over any other encumbrance. We cannot make any law to deprive a State of property it has acquired. For instance, large advances have been made from the Treasury of Victoria to municipalities for distribution amongst farmers with a view to buying wire netting. That is a debt due to the Crown, collected by the municipalities, and paid to the Crown, and the law under which the money was advanced made the amount advanced to each farmer a first charge upon his land.

speech.para: That first charge is practically a first mortgage belonging to the State.. It is a part of the property of the State, just as much as are the public buildings of Melbourne, which we cannot tax. If we purport now by a law to make this tax a charge, not only on the man's interest in the land, but on the State of Victoria's interest in the land, we are attempting something that manifestly we cannot do.

talk.start.para: . - The honorable member's explanation of his amendment has not, I submit with all deference, advanced his position. He has simply said that, where under any State law there is a charge by the State against any lands, we ought to make our law subject to that charge. Does the honorable member say that we cannot make ours a first charge ? We say that ours shall be the first charge.
- We cannot do it.

- Never mind whether we can. Wesay we can. The honorable member wants us to amend our clause so as to make our charge subject to any existing charge to a State, created under the law of a State. First of all, we have a perfect right to create a first charge which will supersede the right of a State under any existing State law, and, secondly, I say that only in a case where the State has acted under its powers and actually seized a property will a difficulty arise.
- How does possession make any difference?
- I am supposing that the State has seized the land - forfeited it, and actually got it. Section 114 of the Constitution is as follows: -

quote.para: A State shall not, without the consent of the Parliament of the Commonwealth, raise or maintain any naval or military force, or impose any tax on property of any kind belonging to the Commonwealth, nor shall the Commonwealth impose any tax on property of any kind belonging to a State.

speech.para: The whole question is whether a right, which may be enforced on a happening of conditions, amounts to anything within the prohibition under section 114. If it does not, we have a perfect right to impose the charge; if it does, we have no right. The question is whether this charge comes within section 114, and, in my opinion, it does not.

talk.start.para: - That settles it.

- The honorable member has his opinion, and has expressedit. I assume that he will admit that there is a difference between' a charge and a' tax. It is a question whether " tax " in the section means "charge"; that is to. say, whether there is no real fundamental distinction between the imposition of a tax and the right to do something in furtherance of a penalty in reference to the collection of a tax. Surely that must be arguable? I submit, further, that if the honorable member be right, there is no necessity for the words he proposes, because the Constitution imposes the limitation, which must be read into the words of the clause as it stands. The proposed words are either a dangerous attempt to limit our powers, or they are superfluous; and in either case they cannot be accepted.

. - I have looked into the question a little, and it strikes me that the well-known equitable principle applies, namely, that the first in time is the first in right. In the South Australian Act, it is provided that the tax shall be a first charge, but that cannot supersede any Federal charge that may be made prior, nor could any Commonwealth charge supersede, any charge payable to the State if the latter be first in time.
- That is not what the Attorney-General said, but rather that the tax would take priority of State charges. .

- I think that what I say was the effect of the Attorney-General's argument. The Crown of the State and the Crown of the Commonwealth have equal rights in this matter, because, in the Excise case and in some American cases, it has been held that the powers of taxation are independent - in other words, that the States have independent powers and the Commonwealth has independent powers. We have, therefore, the Crown in two equal capacities ; and the first exercise of the capacity is the first charge.

.- I think that the view expressed by the honorable member for Angas .is the correct view. The State can act completely in its own jurisdiction, and the Commonwealth cannot limit or interfere with any valid exercise of its powers of taxation.
- That is, if the State has actually exercised the powers.

- If a debt is due to the State, it can be created a charge on the land, and the Commonwealth . cannot interfere in any way with that charge when' once operative ; on the other hand, if the Commonwealth, in the exercise of its powers of taxation, is in first, the State cannot limit, impede, or hinder that power in any way. As the clause stands, I think that is how the .Court would construe it; and the honorable member for Flinders is simply saying in his amendment what we all agree is the law at the present time.
- Except the AttorneyGeneral.
- I understand that the Attorney-General accepts that' view-
- I said that, at best; the words suggested by the honorable member for Flinders were superfluous.
- If the State exercises its powers, and a charge has been created, the Attorney-General does not suggest that the Commonwealth can come in and take away that charge from the State?
- I said difficulty would only arise where a State had actually exercised its powers.
- When the State has done that before the Commonwealth charge came into existence, does the Attorney-General suggest that the Commonwealth can interfere ?

- The honorable member desires to know whether the Commonwealth charge could supersede that of the State, when the latter has seized land, and I said that there was a difficulty ; but I thought that it would not.
- Supposing the State has not seized the land?
- If the State has not seized the land, but simply declared that a charge shall exist, I regard that as an exercise of the power; and that really is the proposal in the Bill.
- The Courts will decide that question under the Constitution.

- Quite so. Our contention is that the Commonwealth and the State is each sovereign within its own jurisdiction ; and the whole question is, which charge has been first created, for that is the one which will stand under the Constitution.

. - I think it is very likely that the honorable member for Angas and the honorable member for Darling Downs have arrived at the correct conclusion; but it is quite inconsistent with the view of the AttorneyGeneral. I specially asked that honorable gentleman whether the object of the clause is to impose this Federal charge in priority to existing State charges, and I understood him to say, more than once, that that was the object. Of course, if the honorable member withdraws from his position now, there is no more to be said ; and I shall not press the amendment. I am inclined, on consideration, to agree with the view of the honorable member for Angas and the honorable member for Darling Downs ; but I hope the AttorneyGeneral will admit that, in reference to the cost of wire-netting, advances to settlers, and so forth, we are not attempting to make a Federal charge in priority. It would greatlyrelieve the constitutional uncertainty which surrounds a good deal of this measure if the Attorney-General would say. that such is the fact.

.- The most amusing part of the utteranceof the honorable member for Flinders was that in which he asked the Attorney-General to state something that that gentleman has said it is not necessary to state. What difference would a statement make? The Attorney-General would be very unwise to make a statement at all ; he had better leave the matter as it is, and allow the Court to interpret the rights of the states. I see no necessity for the Attorney-General to embody the suggestion of the honorable member for Flinders in the clause, nor to make any statement such as is desired.
- Cannot the AttorneyGeneral speak for himself?

- I represent the people just as much as does the Attorney-General. However, there seems to be no need to discuss the matter further, since the legal gentlemen have convinced one another that the Attorney-General is right.

speech.para: Amendment (by Mr. W. H. Irvine) negatived -

quote.para: That after the word " whatever," line 3, the following words be inserted: - "Subject to any existing charge to a State createdunder the law of a State."

That after the word "liability," line11, the following words be inserted, "or after the expiration of six months from the date on which' the tax became due and payable unless registered under sub-section two of this section."

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: - Will the Attorney- General see that such powers are delegated to the Deputy Commissioner in each State as will enable inquiries to be conducted in the State in which the land is situated ?

quote.para: That the following words be added to subclause 1 : - " Provided further that a purchaser shall be deemed to have made due inquiry who has made inquiry of the Commissioner as prescribed."

talk.start.para: .- I move -

quote.para: That the following words be added to the clause : - " (3.) The Commissioner shall, upon the application in writing of any person addressed to him, stating in such application the particulars of the property in respect of which information is required as to the Land Tax and other moneys due or payable thereon under this Act, and upon payment of a fee of One shilling, forthwith procure and give to such applicant, or send by registered letter by post to the person so applying (whose name and address shallbe stated in such application) a certificate in writing, signed by or on behalf of the Commissioner, in which certificate it shall be stated what (if any) Land Tax and other moneys and interest are due or payable under this Act in respect of such property, with the particulars of such Land Tax and other moneys and interest, and when the same became due or payable or that no such Land Tax or other moneys are then due or payable, as the case may be. The production of such certificate so signed shall for all purposes whatsoever be deemed conclusive proof that at the date thereof no Land Tax or other moneys were due or payable under this Act other than those stated in such certificate in respect of such properly."

speech.para: While the Attorney-General has resolved that inquiry may be made of the Commissioner, it will not be incumbent upon that officer to return an answer. In Victoria, rates are a charge on the property on which they are assessed, and it used to be the practice in connexion with land transactions to inquire of the clerk of the municipality in which the land was situated what amount, if any, was owing on it in respect of rates. In one instance, the clerk stated that nothing was due when there was really a debt of some pounds, and two or three years later the municipality sought to recover the debt from the purchaser of the land, who had been misled by the clerk's reply to his inquiry. Chi the case going to the Full Court, it was held that the clerk's certificate did not bind the municipality, and the purchaser of the land had to pay the rates. This was seen to be unjust, and the Local Government Act of 1903 contains a provision, of which my amendment is virtually a copy, requiring council clerks to reply to applications in writing, and the replies so given bind the municipalities. This provision seems to be a complement to the proviso just inserted by the Attorney-General.

talk.start.para: .-I cannot accept the amendment, because the proviso just inserted does all that should be asked. We do not wish to deter persons from buying land by reason of the fact that they may thus be acquiring concealed liabilities ; but as the clause now stands, a bona fide purchaser for value who. has made due inquiry will be in the same position as such a purchaser is in other respects under the Real Property Acts of New South Wales and Victoria, and the Torrens Act of South Australia. When such a man has made due inquiry, and has been informed that the land which he wishes to purchase is not liable for taxation, he cannot subsequently be called upon to pay.

.- I think that the Attorney-General ought to accept this harmless necessary addition to the clause, which will be of great assistance to solicitors and others interested in the transfer of land. Without some such provision, it may be impossible to obtain a reply from the Commissioner, while the public may be kept waiting for months for replies, to the great hindrance of business. The acceptance of the amendment would not weaken the Bill, and would greatly assist all who have dealings in land.

. - Will it be necessary that all inquiries in respect to transactions in land coming within the scope of the Bill shall be addressed to Melbourne, or to the Seat of Government, before it can be known whether there is any tax due on such land ? If so, the settlement of land transactions in distant States will be unworkable, and the whole system will prove most cumbersome. Could not Deputy Commissioners or some other officers be appointed to furnish the information and give the necessary acquittance?
- I said just now that that would be done. The Commissioner may delegate such powers.
- Would it not be advisable to make provision for the appointment of a Deputy Commissioner in each State capital?
-There is such a provision in the Bill.

. - The Attorney- General might well accept the Amendment proposed by the honorable member for Gippsland. The new proviso proposed by the Attorney-General deals only with the position of the purchaser, who shall be deemed to have made " due inquiry " on his making inquiry of the Commissioner as prescribed. The honorable member for Gippsland suggests, however, that if provision were made for the giving of a certificate delay would be avoided.
- What would that certificate amount to?
- It would be conclusive evidence that the taxhad been paid, and would he produced by the vendor.
- And the vendor and purchaser would be able to settle up at once.
- Yes. I would point out that under the clause as it stands the settlement of a land transaction at Townsville might be delayed for three weeks if inquiry had to be made from the Deputy

speech.para: Commissioner at Brisbane as to whether or not the tax on the land had been paid.

talk.start.para: - And evidence as to due inquiry having been made would also have to be obtained.
- That is so. The honorable member's amendment would not destroy the effect of the clause, and I am quite sure that it would give satisfaction.

- - The course proposed by me seems to he ?i perfectly convenient and proper way of securing that which the honorable' member for Gippsland desires. I wish to make it clear that once the Commissioner has said that there is no charge on a piece of land, his word, irrespective- of whether or not he has made a mistake, will be final. " Due_ inquiry " merely means asking the Commissioner whether there is any charge on the land. '
- But the Bill does not provide that, the Commissioner is to reply to such an inquiry.

- There are many parts of Australia where there are no Commonwealth officers, but where there is a lot of land changing hands. We are dealing, not with a _ two-penny half -penny duckpond, but with a continent, and we cannot stud it all over with land officers or Deputy Commissioners. We can only do our best, and the Committee has the assurance that the Government fully realize how necessary it is to place no obstacle in the way of land settlement. We provide for due inquiry being made, and every facility will be given for making inquiry of the Commissioner, his deputies, or any officer to whom he chooses to delegate this power.

. - I am surprised that the Attorney-General should refuse to accept this amendment, more especially since, according to his own statement, this measure will be administered, not merely by one Commissioner, but by a large number of subordinate officers in various parts of the Commonwealth. Those officers are not placed under any obligation to reply to inquiries.
- And there is no acquittance. -

- That is so. Delay may take place in replying to letters of inquiry, unless there is cast- upon the officers a clear-cut responsibility to supply a certificate.- I can understand the Attor ney-General not desiring to assent straight away to the form of this amendment, because it is rather long, and may need to be examined ; but if he were to agree to an amendment providing that the Commissioner " shall give such certificate as may be prescribed, " my difficulty would be overcome.
- Under the clause as amended the Commissioner may do that.

- But we require that he shall be compelled to supply a certificate when. requested to do so. Promptitude and certainty are above all things necessary in connexion with dealings in land, otherwise friction and difficulty must occur. I hope that the Attorney-General will at least promise to consider the matter, for it is one of great practical convenience.

. - I submitted my amendment as a practical matter, and as the result of my experience as a solicitor in investigating titles when acting for purchasers. It is the duty of a solicitor when so acting to see that the title in question is free of all charges, and to make inquiries in respect of all .such matters. The Attorney-General says that the Commissioner may furnish a reply, but we desire that the Bill shall definitely provide that a reply must be made to such inquiry. Before a solicitor can advise a purchaser of land to settle, he must know whether the land tax has been paid, or he may desire to apportion it, in respect of the current year, as between vendor and purchaser. Under the clause as amended it is provided that " due inquiry " will be sufficient to clear a bond fide purchaser of responsibility for the payment of land tax, but he .would have to prove that he had made due inquiry, and might not be able to produce evidence that his letter of inquiry had reached the Commissioner. Under my amendment, if a solicitor acting for a purchaser wrote in due time to the Commissioner for a certificate, and it had not reached him before the day fixed for settlement, he would at once telegraph for a reply, and would be able to make sure that his inquiry had reached its proper destination. I cannot see what objection there is to compelling the Commissioner to answer an inquiry. I am quite willing to adopt the suggestion made by the honorable member for Flinders that the Attorney-General, in the event of his refusing to accept my amendment, should provide in the Bill itself for the Commissioner giving a certificate " as prescribed."

division.header.para: Question - That the words proposed to be added (Mr. Wise's amendment) be so added - put. The Committee divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

quote.para: Every person who, under the provision of this Act, pays any tax for or on behalf of any other person, shall be entitled to recover the same from that other person as a debt, together with the cost of recovery, or to retain or deduct same out of any money in his hands belonging or payable to that other person.

talk.start.para: .- We might extend the clause to cover a class of case which arises chiefly through the operations of wills and settlements, where people will have to pay the whole tax, after paying out various annuities.
