The Attorney- General might try to relieve a man who has to pay all the tax in that way by giving him power to deduct a fair proportion of the tax from the moneys that he has to pay to the annuitants. A man may have an estate which brings in £5,000 a year. He is the legal owner, and liable to pay the tax, but out of that £5,000 he may have to pay £2,000 or £3,000 to different people in annuities. When he pays the tax, in addition to the annuities, his own income will probably have nearly vanished. I suggest the addition of the following words to the clause -

quote.para: Provided that where a taxpayer is liable for the payment of a sum or sums of money charged upon the land in respect of which the tax is payable, such taxpayer shall be entitled to deduct from each sum so charged and payable by him as aforesaid an amount as contribution equal to the proportion which the said sum or sums bear to the full improved value of the said land after such sum or sums have been capitalized on an interest-bearing basis of £5 per centum per annum.

speech.para: That would work out in this way : Take an estate of the full improved value of £150,000, and a taxable unimproved value of £95,000. The man responsible for the tax, as the Bill now stands, would pay £1,59315s.inland taxation. He has to pay an annuity of £1,000 to A, and another of £1,500 to B. £1,000 capitalized at 5 per cent. would be £20,000, which is two- fifteenths of £150,000. Twofifteenths of the annuity of £1,000 is £133 6s. 8d. The annuity of £1,500 capitalized in the same way represents £30,000, which is one-fifth of the total improved value of the estate. One-fifth of £1,500 is £300. Therefore, the man who has to pay the full tax to the Commonwealth would be entitled to deduct from his payment of £1,000 to A the sum of £133 6s. 8d., and from his payment of £1,500 to B the sum of £300. The people in receipt of annuities ought to pay something towards the tax. It was never thought by many people, when making wills and settlements, that the man to whom the property was left, subject to annuities, would have to contend with anything like this. There will be many cases in Australia, where, after the annuities are paid, as they must be, and the land tax is paid, the owner of the land will have nothing left. My amendment will not interfere with any principle in the Bill; it will do justice; and I hope the AttorneyGeneral will give it favorable consideration.

talk.start.para: . - The case put by the honorable member for Wilmot is rather complicated and difficult. No doubt a great deal of hardship may arise in such circumstances, but I was unable to follow the precise scope of the honorable member's amendment. If he will be satisfied by my declaration that I will look into the matter, and that, as far as possible, such cases will be met, I shall be glad to make the offer accordingly.
- Certainly.

.- I should like to call attention to a matter germane to this clause, and to which the honorable member for Grampians directed my notice this evening. He said it was a pity that some allowance was not made in connexion with annuitants, such as the honorable member for Wilmot has mentioned. We passed in clause 29 a provision that where, under a settlement or a will of a person who had died before 1st July, 1910, there was a division amongst the relatives of the settlors, a deduction of £5,000 could be made for the share of each beneficiary from the total assessment against the trustee. Thus, if the total assessment was £40,000, and there were three beneficiaries of, say, £5,000 each, there would be a deduction of £15,000, and the tax would fall on the remaining £25,000. The word "share" does not, I think, cover annuities, and it may be that the Attorney-General could comply with the desire of the honorable member for Wilmot by sufficiently widening the definition of the word. The value of annuities could be capitalized at 4 per cent. or 5 per cent., and the necessary deduction made. The honorable member for Grampians drew my attention to this point, and I ask the Attorney-General to look at the matter in the way I have suggested.
- I shall.

quote.para: If within three years after any land tax has been paid it is discovered that too little in amount has been paid, the taxpayer liable for the tax shall forthwith pay the deficiency :
Provided that nothing in this section shall operate to limit or affect the liability of the taxpayer or any other person under section forty-seven of this Act.

talk.start.para: . - Ido not see the necessity for this clause in view of clause 50. The latter provides that no statute of limitations shall affect any action or remedy for the recovery of land tax, while the clause under discussion says that if within three years after any land tax has been paid it is discovered that too little an amount has been forwarded the taxpayers will forthwith pay the deficiency.

. - We, in Australia, have always prided ourselves on the simplicity with which properties can be transferred under the various Land Acts of the States. Whenever property over the value of £5,000 is cut up, any solicitor, before he can pass the title of any block, has to find out whether there is any liability or charge attached ; and if, as here provided, we make this tax a perpetual charge on the land, all sorts of transfers and mortgages will be tied up. This will increase the cost of preparing transfers, and of mortgages, even of small allotments, below the value of £5,000, and will generally cause delay and trouble. I think the AttorneyGeneral might provide that, if no claim is made within three years, the purchaser or person taking the mortgage shall have a clean title. Unless an amendment of this kind is made great difficulty will arise, especially in distant parts of the country from which it will not be easy to communicate with the Commissioner in Melbourne or at Yass-Canberra ; and people who desire to have money in a hurry on mortgage will have to wait. .

. - The clauses of the Bill from 45 to 52, inclusive, deal with the manner in which the land tax may be recovered, and provide for security by making it a charge on the land. Clause 55 deals with other cases where there have been simply a shortage in the payment without either misstatement or undervaluation; and here, of course, there is a clear distinction. It is to meet cases where, through no fault of anybody concerned, there has been a short payment; and the clause is very necessary.

quote.para: Every company which is a taxpayer .... shall at all times be represented by a person residing in Australia .... called the public officer of the Company. ... If the Company fails or neglects to duly appoint a public officer .... it shall be guilty of an offence. Penalty : Fifty pounds for every day during which the failure or neglect continues.

talk.start.para: . - It is not every company or manager of a company who will know that a public officer has to be appointed under this

speech.para: Bill. Under the Income Tax and Companies Acts of the different States public officers have to be registered in connexion with all companies carrying on business here, although registered abroad, and now we are providing for another public officer. Although this is a provision" which may easily be overlooked, the penalty attached is£50 a day, or over £15,000 a year. I should say that a penalty of £5 a day would be quite sufficient.

talk.start.para: - That is the ordinary penalty.
- It would seem as if we were going to extremes in making this an absolutely penal measure; and I ask the Attorney- General to consider the matter.
. - The New Zealand Act provides for a precisely similar penalty.
- Why so much ?

- Honorable members opposite seem to think that the tax, and everything connected with it, are too much ; but I point out that, according, to the Acts Interpretation Act, the clause means that the penalty shall not exceed £50 - it may be anything less. I may add that there is a similar provision also in the New South Wales Act. We are dealing with powerful companies, and we require pecuniary penalties sufficiently high to deter them from wrong-doing.

. - I remember a case in Victoria in which a company, registered in New South Wales, opened a small office in Melbourne, and, under a similar law, was sued for and mulcted in penalties amounting to more than the whole of the assets of the company. If I remember rightly, that took place under an Act which provided that all advertisements in connexion with companies must set out the amount of the paid-up capital; and, there being an omission, an informer sued and recovered the penalty of £10 a day, with the result that the company, through a sheer mistake, was completely ruined.
- The New South Wales Act provides a penalty for such an omission.

- Then, that apparently was not known to the company. These offences are very small, and may arise from pure accident. The question was raised on a Bill recently before us, and a number of honorable members expressed a doubt asto whether, when a fixed penalty is mentioned as in this case, it has not to be enforced. A limit of£10 a day would be ample. At the end of one hundred days, such a fine would have amounted to £1,000, and not much harm would be done if the company omitted to register for that period. It must be remembered that the general public knows little of what we are enacting, not one man in a hundred reading our legislation. Since I left the State Parliament, I seldom read the measures submitted to it, or even the reports of its proceedings, and it is hardly likely that many members of the general public follow our proceedings very closely. I move -

quote.para: That the word "Fifty" be left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof the word " Ten."

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

quote.para: Every contract agreement or arrangement made or entered into, in writing or verbally, shall so far as it has or purports to have the purpose or effect of in any way, directly or indirectly,

item.label: (a)
item.para: altering the incidence of any land tax; or

item.label: (b)
item.para: relieving any person from liability to pay any land tax or making any return ; or

item.label: (c)
item.para: defeating evading or avoiding any duty or liability imposed on any person by this Act; or

item.label: (d)

quote.para: That after the word " verbally," line 2, the words " whether before or after the commencement of this Act" be inserted.

talk.start.para: - Is it intended that, in cases where tenants have agreed to pay all rates, taxes, and charges whatsoever, the agreement shall be null and void so far as taxation proposed by the Bill is concerned ?

.- The clause is more important than seems to. be realized. Only yesterday my attention was drawn to it by a firm of solicitors, who said that it would very much hamper operations in regard to the development of certain mining leases in South Australia. Under the law of that State, an apportionment is provided for where a lessee has seven years of his term to run ; but future leases are left to the usual operation of the law of contract. My impression is that the High Court will have something to say about this provision, which does not seem ancillary to the purposes of the measure'. Of course, where a leasehold has a sale value, it will be taxable. The provision may be constitutional regarding existing leases, but I doubt whether it can be made to apply to future leases. As the Opposition is willing to facilitate the consideration of the remaining clauses to-morrow, nothing will be lost by reporting progress now.

. - The clause must be read in conjunction with clauses 26A and 26B, of which the former takes out of the operation of the measure all Crown leases other than perpetual leases, and leases giving the right to purchase. Clause 26b deals specifically with the lia bility of lessees, both before and after the Act. Clause 59, with which we are now dealing, relates to all other attempts to evade the Act, and whatever they may be, they are not necessarily those to whichthe honorable member for Darling Downs has referred. They seem to be covered by clause 26B; and, in so far as they are not, this clause will apply. The clause intends, as far as possible, to place the incidence of the tax on the person who ought properly to pay it, and will not permit of any evasion, nor of any attempt to evade.

. - I think that this clause goes, a great deal further than the AttorneyGeneral intends. Under the amendment, it will be retrospective and may, so to speak, rip up numerous contracts for the sale of land that have already been entered into. A person who has subdivided and sold part of his land will have altered the incidence of the tax, and the mere fact of his having done so before the passing of this Bill will make the contracts of sale absolutely void. We are going to give people opportunities to cancel contracts already entered into, and are making it an offence to enter into contracts that will vary the incidence of this measure before it actually comes into force. Surely it was never intended that we should pass retrospective legislation by which contracts in existence shall be declared void as between the parties who have legally entered into them with their eyes open. They are to be void if they interfere in any way with the incidence of the land tax, or relieve any person of liability to pay the tax, or to make a return under this Bill. Any one who cuts up an estate, and sells part of it, will be relieved of certain liabilities under this Bill; and all contracts entered into for the sale of that land can be voided. I do not think that the Attorney- General intended that that should be the effect of his amendment. Parliament, as a rule, is strongly averse to retrospective legislation, and I suggest that the Attorney-General should leave the clause as originally drafted. Any contract entered into before the passing of the Bill should be legal ; but the clause cannot be made too strong to deal with any person who enters info a contract after the passing of the Bill, with a view to altering the incidence of the tax, or of attempting to evade it. The clause, as proposed to be amended, will go further than any legislation of the kind of which I know.

talk.start.para: - Will the Attorney-General explain the exact effect of the amendment?
- I have already done so.

. - Can the Attorney-General state whether the officers who are to have free access to all documents and papers are to be permanent members of the Public Service, or whether they may be officers temporarily employed? We have removed the penalty clause dealing with secrecy, but if an officer in the Public Service discloses any private information which he acquires over and above the mere valuation of the land, we have control over him.

. - An exactly similar provision is made in the New Zealand Act. The clause gives a general and very necessary power. We cannot limit the Commissioner's power by saying that he may enter upon land but not into buildings, or look at deeds but not at books.

- In New Zealand the officers mentioned are particular officers, authorized underthe Act. Mere temporary officers, employed to value land, ought not to be given authority to examine all sorts of private books and papers.
- The wording of the New Zealand Act is exactly the same.

talk.start.para: . - Does not the Attorney-General think that it is time to adjourn? He has made very great progress, and it ought not to take long now to dispose of the remaining clauses of the Bill. He smiles; but I guarantee that if he had been on this side with his friends, the Bill would have taken about three months to get through the House.
- If the honorable member had been on this side, it would have taken three minutes. It would have taken just as long as it would have taken to apply the " gag."

- The honorable member is taking another course. He does not believe in that kind of thing; and nobody else, I hope, will attemptto "gag" a proposal of this kind through, so that the remark is entirely out of place. I merely suggest that he has made good progress, and that it is time for us to go home.

. - I am very ready to suggest that we should go home ; but it is very obvious that we must finish the Bill at some time. What I suggest is an arrangement whereby we shall finish the clauses as they stand in the Bill by dinner time to-morrow - that is, in about three hours - and take on Friday the recommittal and the new clauses, about which there can be very little discussion. That is an arrangement to which I think honorable members might come. We cannot go on for ever. I do not believe in sitting late- indeed, I am very reluctant to do so. This afternoon we wasted four hours on clause 44, and discussed it long after there was practically nothing to discuss. I do hope that the arrangementI have indicated can be arrived at.

.- It is impossible for one to pledge his word that honorable members will not speak on a matter, unless there is an absolute concert. We on this side will facilitate getting through the Bill by the time mentioned, but, considering the importance of one clause, I cannot pledge honorable members not to discuss it at greater length. The Attorney-General will remember that on two occasions where I said on behalf of others that, as far as. possible, we would terminate discussion at a certain time, we came to the exact clause mentioned by him at the time named. I would ask the honorable gentleman to accept an assurance of that kind. As far as I am personally concerned, and I believe I speak for the Opposition generally, we will facilitate the measure being passed through Committee by half-past 6 o'clock tomorrow evening.
- What about the recommittals ?
- I believe, but cannot positively promise, that they will be disposed of by Friday afternoon. I do not think that there will be much difficulty about the new clauses.

. - Of course, I understand that the honorable member for Angas cannot bind every one on his own side of the Committee any more than we can bind the supporters of the Government. I am satisfied with the honorable member's assurance. I understand that he agrees that, as far as he can speak for the Opposition, we shall dispose of the Bill in Committee before dinner to-morrow afternoon.
- I cannot speak absolutely as to the recommittals. I do not say that we shall get through all the recommittals on Friday. It will be time to-morrow to speak about them.

- May I ask for the hearty co-operation of honorable members opposite to dispose of the Bill as far as possible by Friday at 4 o'clock? The Acting Leader of the Opposition seems to think that there is some catch in what I am proposing, but I am putting the matter quite fairly.

. - I should like the AttorneyGeneral to understand that I take what he has said as being uttered in good faith. It is not a good thing to begin by imputing motives. I hesitate to commit myself with respect to any particular time for disposing of so important a Bill, though I have no wish to see it delayed one minute longer than is absolutely necessary. A measure like this, however, is far too important to be bludgeoned through without proper discussion, and I can commit myself to no course of action which would prevent fair discussion. Arrangements have, however, been suggested by the two members of the Opposition who have borne the brunt of the criticism. They have assured the Attorney-General that they will, as far as possible, facilitate the passage of the Bill, and that there will be no undue delay. I hope that there may be none.
- All I want is the honorable member's co-operation. Does he fall into line with the arrangement?
- The honorable gentleman will not lose anything by adjourning now.
